text: assembly will hear and dress by his
Excellency Luis Rodolfo abhinadar
Corona
president of the Dominican Republic I
request protocol to escort his
Excellency
on behalf of the general assembly I have
the honor to welcome his Excellency
Lewis Rodolfo abinadir Corona president
of the Dominican Republic and to invite
him to address the assembly
his friend
the Excellency Mr Dennis Francis
president of the 78th regular session of
the general assembly
of the United Nations
your Excellency Mr Antonio guterres
Secretary General of the United Nations
heads of state and governments
honorable heads of Delegation ladies and
gentlemen
as we enter the second decade of the
21st century Humanity faces inherited
challenges and new obstacles that
require action
we must see these calamities as
opportunities that compel us to work
together to overcome them
the Dominican Republic has the firm
commitment that we can build a model of
inclusive human development that is just
and sustainable
however it is legitimate for us to
wonder
whether we are really on track to
achieve such an outcome
the various crises caused by climate
change have had devastating impacts on
our planet and societies such as
droughts rising sea levels loss of
biodiversity
extreme weather events amongst others
these impacts have generated an
environmental
liability that significantly threatens
all of the progress achieved in recent
decades
as a developing economy with a negative
carbon footprint we are making our
contribution to mitigating climate
change by incentivizing the use of
renewable energies but we know that this
is only one step on the long road to
sustainability because we still have
significant dependence on fossil fuels
oil is still important to us
I take this opportunity to draw
attention to the practice
of Supply control by exporting countries
in order to keep
crude oil prices High to the detriment
of importing countries in this assembly
representative of all we should discuss
and approve a financial mechanism to
guarantee the stability of crude oil
prices
for low and middle income importing
countries such as mine important steps
have been taken to address the climate
emergency such as the recent adoption of
the convention for the conservation and
sustainable use of marine biological
diversity in areas Beyond national
jurisdiction known as bbnj
a convention which I will be signing
this afternoon
but many more
and far more significant steps remain
outstanding such as adopting a
multi-dimensional vulnerability index
mvi applicable to all developing
countries or the implementation of the
loss and damage fund to provide
financial assistance to the nation's
most vulnerable to the effects of
climate change
I would also like to highlight the
international Summit to be held in
Antigua and Bermuda in May 2024 on small
island developing States
in which our country will be present as
a member of the Preparatory committee
it is also urgent to create a
concessional financing mechanism for
middle-income countries
so they can meet
the challenges of achieving the
sustainable development goals
the lack of access to adequate resources
was one of the reasons why many
countries fail to meet the Millennium
development goals
as the Secretary General has stated the
international
Financial system is broken
the Dominican Republic strongly believes
in an in-depth reform of the
International Financial architecture
that could benefit all countries in an
equitable way
another of the harmful effects of
climate change effects in particular our
Caribbean region
here I am referring to the massive
proliferation of sargassum this seaweed
devours Caribbean coasts including the
coasts of the United States and Mexico
and has serious economic social and
environmental impacts especially for
tourism which represents up to 75
percent of some Caribbean Nations
economies
the Dominican Republic has created a
multi-sectoral round table to deal with
this problem and we hope that developed
countries will contribute to the
solution
Mr President
one of the pillars of our commitment to
achieve a fairer social contract and a
more effective state has been and will
always be the fight against corruption
Dominican citizens have taken this on as
a response to one of their main demands
the various International indicators own
the perception of corruption confirm the
progress that my government has made in
this regard
on a different matter I would like to
take this opportunity before this
assembly to reiterate the Jamaican
Republic's candidacy for the UN Human
Rights Council for the period
2024-26 elections will be held next
month
this candidacy represents our firm
commitment to the defense of Human
Rights
distinguished colleagues
looking at the island of Hispaniola from
space you could do this on your mobile
phone for example using Google Earth
you can see a palpable and
heart-wrenching difference one half of
the island is green and flourishing that
is the Dominican Republic which has
prioritized the conservation and
sustainable management of its natural
resources
the other half
is devoid of that rich Forest cover
this is a reflection of Haiti's dramatic
deforested landscape
this natural Frontier is not only a
geography lesson it is a potent reminder
of what awaits the world if we continue
to ignore Nature's alarms
ladies and gentlemen here to you today
suffers not only from an environmental
tragedy but also from political and
social instability that may become a
threat to the entire region
I'm not happy to have to recall the call
I made two years ago to this General
Assembly when I said
since this government took office we
have been warning of the possibility
that the Haitian situation could spill
over its borders into our country
becoming a factor of insecurity for the
entire region
that is why this community of Nations
once and for all has to take up the
Haitian issue at the highest level of
priority with permanent monitoring
today too late two years later
the harsh reality of that warning is
coming home to rust a small group of
Haitian private individuals have resumed
the construction of an illegal diversion
canal in Haitian territory to extract
water from the dahabon river in
violation of Border treaties between our
two countries
the International Community should
realize that the dahabon river
originates in Loma de Cabrera and most
of its 55 kilometers run through our
territory before emptying out into Bay
of montanillo in montecriste only two
kilometers run through Haitian territory
it is not small stretch on the Haitian
side that the canal is being dug the
information available to us indicates
that this is a maneuver to control the
Water by a small economic political
Elite in order to profit from its sale
to small producers in the area
the idea behind this project has never
been officially communicated to the
Dominican government nor has
documentation been provided on its scope
environmental impacts or the identity of
its final beneficiaries
despite the highly limited information
available our analysis shows that the
project
puts at risk access to water for
hundreds of Dominican and Haitian
farming families Downstream of the
Canal's construction sites
moreover the project puts at risk of
flooding an industrial park which is 300
meters Downstream from the from the
canal as well as nineteen thousand
Haitian workers in Mendez
as well as inhabitants in the Border
towns of dehabon and Juana Mendes
additionally it would have harmful
ecological impacts affecting Salado
lagoon one of the main wetlands in the
Dominican Republic
since April 2021 our government has
repeatedly sought
for the haishin authorities to stop the
unilateral and illegal construction of
this project the Haitian government
itself
has indicated that it is not a
government-run project but it has not
been able to stop it because of
institutional weakness and the public
order and security crisis ongoing in
that country
the situation has already led to
a fragile animosity on both sides of the
Border
faced with this illegal International
act committed by private individuals and
a part of the river that is on Haitian
territory the Dominican government has
been forced to take forceful measures
such as closing the border with Haiti in
order to guarantee security and our
national interest as well as to protect
our Rivers environments and agricultural
production
we do not have nor do we seek or desire
a confrontation with the Haitian people
but we Face uncontrollable actors who
ferment insecurity in Haiti for their
particular interests and who are now
conspiring against their own government
stability and the security of Water
Resources Mr President
there can be no doubt that the problem
of Haiti is no longer just
in Haiti it is in the hands of the
International Community
that is why we strongly support the
responsible proposition of the president
of the United States Mr Joe Biden
expressed yesterday from this Rostrum
and which we will repeat now
the security Council must authorize
urgently the un-backed security Mission
as a matter of
urgency
the security Council has already passed
three important resolutions creating a
sanctions regime
an effort to stop the illicit flow of
arms and a call for the creation of a
multinational Force to assist the
Haitian National Police
as requested
by the government of that country and
the Secretary General of this
organization
we applaud
Kenya's major gesture of solidarity in
leading the multinational Force as well
as the gestures of Jamaica and Bahamas
in providing personnel
I take this opportunity to thank in
particular the president of Kenya
William Ruto for his solidarity and
humanitarian willingness to lead via
that mission the search for peace and
stability for the Haitian people
moreover
we urge all those countries that are
considering playing a role in this
commendable effort to act with
determination
what is happening in Haiti is a
breakdown of Law and Order caused by
criminal elements without any political
or ideological claims and therefore
welcoming the Haitian Authority's
request for assistance by sending a
multinational force would be in keeping
with the spirit and the letter of the
United Nations Charter and the Mandate
of this organization in accordance with
international law as a way of
guaranteeing the peace
we are all aware that the process of
achieving peace in Haiti must be
undertaken together with the social and
political agreement
in this regard we commend the noble
efforts made by the CARICOM group of
eminent leaders to reach a political
agreement that will allow the greatest
possible legitimacy of the acceptance
for the acceptance of a multinational
force in the holding a fair free and
transparent elections in this regard I
wish to acknowledge prime minister
Andrew holness of Jamaica for all of his
efforts
I also wish to thank the Secretary
General for his work in addressing this
crisis
we call on him to redouble those efforts
to achieve the immediate deployment of a
multinational force in Haiti
we also call on the security Council to
pass a resolution as outlined already
and to do it now because time has run
out
Mr President
for centuries
of often difficult coexistence with the
Haitian people the Dominican Republic
has given clear signs of untiring
solidarity Haiti has significant needs I
would like to reiterate our solidarity
with the Haitian people
but without forgetting that our main
responsibility is to defend the
interests of the Dominican people
that is what we have always done that is
what we are doing now and you can rest
assured that that is what we will
continue to do
because there is no and never can be a
Dominican solution to the Haitian
problem
ladies and gentlemen
let us not wait for the next warming to
be the story of a tragedy foretold
at this
session of the general assembly we
should Mark a Renaissance in our
Collective determination to forge a more
secure inclusive and sustainable future
for Haiti and for all
I would make one final call
the current Global scenario challenges
us to act not only as individual Nations
but as a United World with a shared
vision and common purpose
history will judge us not just for The
Words which we
pronounce in these hallowed halls but
more crucially for our actions on the
ground
let's not fail the future thank you very
much
[Applause]
assembly I wish to thank the president
of the Dominican Republic
for the statement just made
and I request protocol 2 is called his
Excellency
